definitions.definition: Situated close to, or even below, the ground or another normal reference plane ; not high or lofty .
examples: in a low valley, ringed by low hills
a low wall  a low shelf

subdefinitions.definition: Pertaining to (or, especially of a language: spoken in) in an area which is at a lesser elevation, closer to sea level (especially near the sea), than other regions.

examples: the pitch (or: the ball) was low

definitions.definition: Of less than normal height or upward extent or growth, or of greater than normal depth or recession; below the average or normal level from which elevation is measured.
examples: the Mississippi is unusually low right now

definitions.definition: Not high in status , esteem , or rank , dignity , or quality . ( Compare vulgar . )
examples: the low officials of the bureaucracy
Now that was low even for you!

definitions.definition: Disparaging ; assigning little value or excellence.
examples: She had a low opinion of cats. He took a low view of dogs.
the low point in her career

definitions.definition: Lacking health or vitality , strength or vivacity ; feeble ; weak .

subdefinitions.definition: Having few hit points remaining; damaged .

definitions.definition: Small, not high (in amount or quantity, value, force, energy, etc).
examples: My credit union charges a low interest rate.   Jogging during a whiteout , with such low temperatures and low visibility, is dangerous.   The store sold bread at low prices, and milk at even lower prices.   The contractors gave a low estimate of the costs. low cholesterol   a low voltage wire   a low number

subdefinitions.definition: Having a small or comparatively smaller concentration of (a substance, which is often but not always linked by "in" when predicative).
Depleted , or nearing deletion; lacking in supply.

examples: low protozoan animals, low cryptogamic plants, and other low organisms

definitions.definition: Favoring simplicity (see e.g. low church , Low Tory).
Grave in pitch, due to being produced by relatively slow vibrations (wave oscillations); flat .
examples: The note was too low for her to sing.
Generally, European men have lower voices than their Indian counterparts.
They spoke in low voices so I would not hear what they were saying.
Why would you want to play heavy metal at such a low volume?

definitions.definition: Made with a relatively large opening between the tongue and the palate ; made with (part of) the tongue positioned low in the mouth, relative to the palate.
Lesser in value than other cards, denominations, suits, etc.
Not rich or seasoned ; offering the minimum of nutritional requirements; plain , simple .
Designed for a slow (or the slowest) speed .

main_definition: Situated close to, or even below, the ground or another normal reference plane ; not high or lofty .
secondary_definitions: Of less than normal height or upward extent or growth, or of greater than normal depth or recession; below the average or normal level from which elevation is measured.
Not high in status , esteem , or rank , dignity , or quality . ( Compare vulgar . )
Disparaging ; assigning little value or excellence.
Lacking health or vitality , strength or vivacity ; feeble ; weak .
Small, not high (in amount or quantity, value, force, energy, etc).
( especially in biology ) Simple in complexity or development.
( chiefly in several set phrases ) Favoring simplicity (see e.g. low church , Low Tory).
( in several set phrases ) Being near the equator .
( acoustics ) Grave in pitch, due to being produced by relatively slow vibrations (wave oscillations); flat .
( phonetics ) Made with a relatively large opening between the tongue and the palate ; made with (part of) the tongue positioned low in the mouth, relative to the palate.
( card games ) Lesser in value than other cards, denominations, suits, etc.
( now rare ) Not rich or seasoned ; offering the minimum of nutritional requirements; plain , simple . [from 17th c.]
( of an automobile, gear, etc ) Designed for a slow (or the slowest) speed .
